title: Synthetic Recap
body:
**Knicks Grind Out Gritty Victory as Starks’ Shooting Sinks Clippers**

NEW YORK – In a defensive battle reminiscent of a bygone era, the New York Knicks clawed their way to an 89-80 victory over the Los Angeles Clippers at Madison Square Garden. But the final score fails to tell the real story of this 1997 contest, a tale defined entirely by the singular, explosive performance of Knicks guard John Starks.

On a night where offensive rhythm was a rarity, Starks authored a masterpiece. The veteran unleashed a game-high 38 points, a staggering total in a contest where the teams combined for just 169. Every time the Clippers threatened to close the gap, Starks answered. He was a whirlwind of relentless drives and cold-blooded jumpers, slicing through the Los Angeles defense almost single-handedly.

While Starks provided the offensive fireworks, the Knicks' trademark defense formed the backbone of the win. Patrick Ewarton anchored the paint, contributing a solid 15 points and 12 rebounds, while Charles Oakley dominated the glass with a game-high 17 rebounds. Their efforts ensured that the Clippers, led by Loy Vaught’s 18 points and 13 rebounds, could never fully recover from Starks’ onslaught.

The Clippers fought valiantly, with Malik Sealy adding 15 points, but they had no counter for the hurricane in a Knicks uniform. Starks’ 38-point outburst was more than just a high-scoring game; it was a historic carry-job, a testament to one man’s will to win on a night when points were at a premium. In the heart of Manhattan, John Starks didn’t just lead his team to a win; he put on a performance for the ages.
